docs.lead_paragraph: Should Web sites that sell baby clothes, toys and pacifiers start posting up-to-the-minute college football scores and pictures of swimsuit models? That might be one way to help expectant fathers make the transition to spit bibs from sports and to parenting from pornography. The query is prompted by results from a recent survey by ComScore Media Metrix, which measures Internet traffic patterns -- including the latest findings on the difference in the Web surfing patterns of expectant mothers and fathers.

headline.main: Compressed Data; Should Baby Web Sites Reach Out to Dad?

docs.abstract: ComScore Media Metrix survey finds that expectant mothers' Web-surfing tends to change towards family and community sites whereas fathers-to-be do not substantially alter Internet activities they pursued before pregnancy; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF there is one thing new parents love more than learning about what makes babies tick, it is recounting the experiences they have had with their own little treasures. New parents are up at all hours, with a lot of tales to tell, questions to ask and products to buy. I'm speaking from first-hand knowledge, being the father of a 10-month-old.

headline.main: The Web Loves Babies, Especially at 4 in the Morning

docs.abstract: New parents have great resource in Internet, where scores of sites offer general advice on child-rearing, archives of articles, product information, baby naming tips, child care help, free e-mail newsletters, messge boards and chat rooms; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnant women have less to fear from cats and litter boxes than they do from undercooked meat, according to a newly published article discussing toxoplasmosis, an infection that can cause miscarriages or damage to fetuses. Pregnant women are often told to steer clear of all contact with cats and cat feces to avoid exposure to the disease.

headline.main: Pregnant Women, Fear Not the Cat

docs.abstract: Yale School of Medicine researcher Dr Jeffrey D Kravetz, in article in Archives of Internal Medicine about toxoplasmosis, finds that pregnant women have less to fear from cats and litter boxes than from undercooked meat; toxoplasmosis is infection that can cause miscarriage or damage fetuses (M)
docs.snippet: Pregnant women have less to fear from cats and litter boxes than they do from undercooked meat, according to a newly published article discussing toxoplasmosis, an infection that can cause miscarriages or damage to fetuses.    Pregnant women are...

docs.lead_paragraph: Low self-esteem is to blame for a host of social ills, from poor academic performance and marital discord to violent crime and drug abuse. Or so goes the gospel, as written over the last several decades by social scientists, self-help book authors and the California Task Force to Promote Self-Esteem and Personal and Social Responsibility, a panel created in 1986 by the California Legislature to conduct a three-year study of the topic.

headline.main: Deflating Self-Esteem's Role in Society's Ills

docs.abstract: Article on research by Dr Brad Bushman of Iowa State University and Dr Roy Baumeister of Case Western Reserve University debunking notion that high or low self-esteem results in good or bad behavior; two find that some people with high self-regard are more likely to lash out aggressively when criticized than those with low self-esteem; drawing (M)
